A reminder to check the label on foods before you buy them, especially if they are labeled with some combination of “healthy”, “low sugar”, “low sodium”, “heart conscious”, etc. In these products companies will sometimes boost salt content to make a food with reduced fat taste better or vice-versa.

Of course, this is no indictment of healthy eating. It’s important to make smart decisions about our diets by choosing fresh foods free of ingredients you cannot pronounce.

via: “Healthy” Foods Not Necessarily Healthier than Their Regular Counterparts – Saving Money – Lifehacker.

Written on March 5, 2010
